description: Adult income dataset (Census Income). Predicts whether annual income exceeds $50K/yr based on census data extracted from the 1994 US Census database.

donor.name: Ron Kohavi
donor.affiliation: Data Mining and Visualization, Silicon Graphics

feature_description.workclass: Private, Self-emp-not-inc, Self-emp-inc, Federal-gov, Local-gov, State-gov, Without-pay, Never-worked
feature_description.education: Bachelors, Some-college, 11th, HS-grad, Prof-school, Assoc-acdm, Assoc-voc, 9th, 7th-8th, 12th, Masters, 1st-4th, 10th, Doctorate, 5th-6th, Preschool
feature_description.marital-status: Married-civ-spouse, Divorced, Never-married, Separated, Widowed, Married-spouse-absent, Married-AF-spouse
feature_description.occupation: Tech-support, Craft-repair, Other-service, Sales, Exec-managerial, Prof-specialty, Handlers-cleaners, Machine-op-inspct, Adm-clerical, Farming-fishing, Transport-moving, Priv-house-serv, Protective-serv, Armed-Forces
feature_description.relationship: Wife, Own-child, Husband, Not-in-family, Other-relative, Unmarried
feature_description.native-country: United-States, Cambodia, England, Puerto-Rico, Canada, Germany, Outlying-US(Guam-USVI-etc), India, Japan, Greece, South, China, Cuba, Iran, Honduras, Philippines, Italy, Poland, Jamaica, Vietnam, Mexico, Portugal, Ireland, France, Dominican-Republic, Laos, Ecuador, Taiwan, Haiti, Columbia, Hungary, Guatemala, Nicaragua, Scotland, Thailand, Yugoslavia, El-Salvador, Trinadad&Tobago, Peru, Hong, Holand-Netherlands

target_values.<=50K: Income less than or equal to $50,000 per year

use_case: Income prediction, socioeconomic analysis, fairness in machine learning research, demographic studies, policy making

dataset_splits.note: Test set has slight different distribution characteristics

data_collection: Extraction from 1994 US Census database with specific filtering conditions to ensure data quality
preprocessing_notes: Missing values marked with '?', requires handling of categorical variables, potential for feature engineering from existing attributes
advantages: Well-studied benchmark dataset, realistic class imbalance, mix of continuous and categorical features, useful for fairness studies
challenges: Missing values in several attributes, imbalanced classes, potential bias in historical census data, sensitive attributes present
ethical_considerations: Contains sensitive demographic information (race, sex, native-country), historical biases in income distribution, widely used in fairness and bias detection research

related_datasets.ACSIncome: Modern alternative from American Community Survey (2014-2018) addressing some limitations of original Adult dataset

citations.author: Ron Kohavi
citations.title: Scaling Up the Accuracy of Naive-Bayes Classifiers: a Decision-Tree Hybrid
citations.venue: Proceedings of the Second International Conference on Knowledge Discovery and Data Mining

original_source.creator: Barry Becker
original_source.publication: Ron Kohavi: Scaling Up the Accuracy of Naive-Bayes Classifiers: a Decision-Tree Hybrid

target_classes.name: <=50K
target_classes.meaning: Income less than or equal to $50,000 per year

dataset_history: Data Collection: Extraction from 1994 US Census database with specific filtering conditions to ensure data quality
inference_notes: Challenges: Missing values in several attributes, imbalanced classes, potential bias in historical census data, sensitive attributes present. Advantages: Well-studied benchmark dataset, realistic class imbalance, mix of continuous and categorical features, useful for fairness studies. Use Case: Income prediction, socioeconomic analysis, fairness in machine learning research, demographic studies, policy making
